results.title: Donald Friend
results.creator_credit: Australia Council and Smart St Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Donald Friend tells of a life spent in such varied locations as northern Queensland, Africa, Ceylon, rural New South Wales and his beloved Bali, and the influences these places had on his art. He also talks of his friendship with many contemporary artists including Russell Drysdale and William Dobell.

results.title: Ethics and the Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of the Age and Harry Gordon, former Editor in Chief of the Herald and Weekly Times, discuss issues relating to journalism’s code of ethics. They discuss what their in-house rules are relating to ethics and integrity within their journalistic world.

results.title: Law Affecting Journalism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of “The Age”, and Harry Gordon, former Editor-in-Chief at “The Herald and Weekly Times”, discuss the law of libel, defamation, and the problems and benefits of these laws in the journalist’s world.

results.title: The Esso Australian Jazz Summit
results.brief_description: Sydney’s famous Bondi Beach came alive with a foot-tapping, head-nodding event, the First Australian Jazz Summit. All styles of jazz were represented, from modern, traditional through to avant-garde. Various ensembles and configurations of players performed, from standard groups to Big Bands, feature soloists and, of course, jam sessions and improvisation. Rated: G

results.title: Crossroads Rock Concert
results.creator_credit: Richard Hodder, Salvation Army and Salvation Army. Australia Southern Territory
results.brief_description: Three Christian rock groups gig together in aid of Salvation Army’s Crossroads Program for Homeless Youth, interspersed with modern parables about being young and different from the crowd. “Crossroads” is a video about, and for, contemporary Christian youth.

results.title: Australian Bush Music
results.brief_description: Features the Mucky Duck Bush Band singing a selection of Australian folk songs, and explains the background of various songs and the instruments used to play them.

results.title: Immigration: the waves that shaped Australia
results.creator_credit: Paul Woolston-Smith and Dept Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
results.brief_description: This video outlines the migrations which have made us what we are - starting with the arrival of First Nations peoples. The landing on the 26th January, 1788, of the officers, marines and convicts of the First Fleet, started successive waves of mostly European migration whose cultures enriched our nation.

results.title: A Town like Alice
results.creator_credit: David Stevens, Henry Crawford and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: Based on Nevil Shute’s best selling novel, “A Town Like Alice” is set against the brutal chaos of World War 11 and centres on two prisoners of war an Englishwoman, Jean Paget and an Australian soldier Joe Harmon, whose romance begins during the takeover of Malaya in World War 11 and takes them to the vast Australian outback.

results.title: Hal Porter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A witty, biting commentary about life and an author’s place in it. Hal Porter reminisces about teaching, acting, producing for the theatre, and his life in Melbourne, Bairnsdale and Japan.

results.title: Christina Stead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
In the only filmed interview with one of Australia’s most popular and respected novelists, Christina Stead is both challenging and revealing.
